title: Classic Margherita Pizza
description: A timeless Neapolitan pizza with San Marzano tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella, and fragrant basil on a thin, crispy crust.
steps: Preheat your oven to the highest setting (ideally 250°C/480°F) with a baking stone or inverted baking sheet inside for at least 30 minutes.
Crush the San Marzano tomatoes by hand, mix with minced garlic, a drizzle of olive oil, and salt to make the sauce.
Divide the dough into two balls and stretch each into a thin round on a floured surface, dusting with semolina to prevent sticking.
Spread a thin layer of tomato sauce over each base, leaving a 1cm border for the crust.
Tear the mozzarella into pieces and distribute evenly over the sauce.
Slide the pizza onto the hot baking stone and bake for 8-10 minutes until the crust is golden and charred in spots.
Remove from the oven, top with fresh basil leaves and a drizzle of olive oil, then serve immediately.

substitutions.note: Use a melting variety for best results
For a quick flatbread pizza alternative
Roast them first for deeper flavor

title: Risotto ai Funghi Porcini
description: A luxuriously creamy Italian risotto made with dried porcini mushrooms, Parmigiano-Reggiano, and a splash of white wine.
steps: Soak the dried porcini mushrooms in 250ml warm water for 20 minutes, then drain and reserve the soaking liquid, straining it through a fine sieve.
Heat the vegetable broth in a saucepan and keep it at a gentle simmer.
In a heavy-bottomed pan, heat olive oil and half the butter over medium heat, then sauté the finely diced shallots until translucent.
Add the soaked porcini mushrooms and cook for 3-4 minutes until fragrant.
Add the arborio rice and toast for 2 minutes, stirring constantly, until the edges become translucent.
Pour in the white wine and stir until fully absorbed, then add the reserved mushroom soaking liquid.
Add the warm broth one ladle at a time, stirring frequently and waiting until each addition is absorbed before adding the next, for about 18-20 minutes.
Remove from heat, stir in the remaining butter and Parmigiano-Reggiano, cover and rest for 2 minutes before serving.

substitutions.note: Use 200g fresh; skip the soaking step

substitutions.replacement: dry vermouth or extra broth with lemon juice
substitutions.note: Vermouth adds herbal complexity
Gives a sharper, saltier finish

title: Spaghetti Aglio e Olio
description: A quintessential Roman pasta dish of spaghetti tossed with golden garlic, red pepper flakes, and parsley in fruity olive oil.
steps: Bring a large pot of heavily salted water to a boil and cook the spaghetti until 1 minute short of al dente, reserving 1 cup of pasta water before draining.
While the pasta cooks, thinly slice the garlic and gently heat it in olive oil over medium-low heat, stirring often, until golden (about 4-5 minutes).
Add the red pepper flakes to the garlic oil and cook for 30 seconds.
Add the drained spaghetti directly to the pan along with 1/2 cup of the reserved pasta water.
Toss vigorously over medium heat for 1-2 minutes until the sauce emulsifies and clings to the pasta, adding more pasta water if needed.
Remove from heat, toss with chopped parsley, and serve with grated Parmigiano-Reggiano if desired.

substitutions.note: Use a rice-corn blend for best texture
Adds smoky heat and depth
Gives a sweeter, more aromatic finish

title: Chicken Tacos al Pastor
description: Smoky, pineapple-marinated chicken tacos inspired by the classic al pastor preparation, served with cilantro, onion, and lime.
steps: Toast the guajillo chiles in a dry pan for 1 minute per side, then soak in hot water for 15 minutes and drain.
Blend the soaked chiles with achiote paste, garlic, vinegar, cumin, and 2 pineapple rings into a smooth marinade.
Coat the chicken thighs in the marinade and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes (or up to overnight).
Grill or pan-sear the marinated chicken over high heat for 5-6 minutes per side until charred and cooked through.
Grill the remaining pineapple rings and half the onion alongside the chicken until caramelized.
Dice the grilled chicken, pineapple, and onion into small pieces.
Warm the corn tortillas on the grill or a dry skillet, then assemble tacos with the chicken, grilled pineapple, onion, cilantro, and a squeeze of lime.

substitutions.note: Traditional al pastor uses pork; adjust cooking time accordingly
Milder and slightly sweeter flavor
Softer texture but no longer gluten-free

title: Guacamole Clásico
description: A vibrant, chunky guacamole made with perfectly ripe avocados, fresh lime juice, serrano peppers, and cilantro.
steps: Halve the avocados, remove the pits, and scoop the flesh into a bowl.
Add the lime juice and salt, then mash with a fork to your preferred consistency, leaving some chunks.
Fold in the diced onion, minced serrano pepper, chopped cilantro, and diced tomato.
Taste and adjust seasoning with more lime juice or salt as needed.
Serve immediately with tortilla chips, or press plastic wrap directly onto the surface to prevent browning.

substitutions.note: Jalapeño is milder; use more to match heat level

substitutions.replacement: flat-leaf parsley with a pinch of cumin
substitutions.note: For those who find cilantro soapy
Adds tropical sweetness for a fruit-forward guacamole

title: Enchiladas Rojas de Queso
description: Corn tortillas stuffed with melted cheese and bathed in a rich, smoky dried chile sauce, topped with crema and pickled onions.
steps: Toast the ancho and guajillo chiles in a dry skillet for 1 minute per side, then soak in hot water for 20 minutes.
Blend the soaked chiles with garlic, cumin, oregano, and chicken broth until very smooth, then strain through a sieve.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a saucepan, pour in the chile sauce, and simmer for 15 minutes until thickened, seasoning with salt.
Lightly fry each tortilla in oil for a few seconds per side to soften, then drain on paper towels.
Dip each tortilla in the warm chile sauce, fill with shredded cheese, roll up, and place seam-side down in a baking dish.
Pour remaining sauce over the enchiladas, top with extra cheese, and bake at 190°C/375°F for 15 minutes.
Serve topped with Mexican crema and sliced onion.

substitutions.note: Similar melt and stretch, slightly milder flavor

substitutions.replacement: sour cream thinned with lime juice
substitutions.note: Mix 1/2 cup sour cream with 1 tbsp lime juice
Makes the dish fully vegetarian

title: Chicken Tikka Masala
description: Tender chunks of spiced yogurt-marinated chicken simmered in a velvety tomato-cream sauce with warm aromatic spices.
steps: Marinate the chicken in yogurt, half the garam masala, turmeric, and salt for at least 1 hour.
Thread chicken onto skewers or spread on a baking sheet and broil for 10-12 minutes until charred on the edges.
In a large pan, heat oil and sauté diced onion until deep golden brown, about 8-10 minutes.
Add garlic, ginger, cumin, remaining garam masala, and kashmiri chili powder, and cook for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Pour in the crushed tomatoes, stir well, and simmer for 15 minutes until the sauce thickens.
Stir in the heavy cream and add the broiled chicken pieces, simmering for another 10 minutes.
Adjust salt and spices to taste, garnish with fresh cilantro, and serve with basmati rice or naan.

substitutions.note: Makes it dairy-free with a slightly sweeter taste
For a vegetarian version; skip the broiling step

substitutions.replacement: paprika with a pinch of cayenne
substitutions.note: Kashmiri chili is mild and vibrant red; paprika mimics the color

title: Chana Masala
description: A hearty North Indian chickpea curry cooked with onions, tomatoes, and a fragrant blend of spices, finished with a squeeze of lemon.
steps: Heat oil in a large pan over medium heat and sauté the diced onion for 6-8 minutes until golden brown.
Add garlic and ginger, cooking for another minute until fragrant.
Stir in the coriander, cumin, turmeric, and half the garam masala, toasting the spices for 30 seconds.
Pour in the pureed tomatoes and cook for 8-10 minutes until the oil separates from the sauce.
Add the drained chickpeas, 1/2 cup water, and salt, then simmer for 15 minutes, mashing a few chickpeas to thicken.
Finish with remaining garam masala, a generous squeeze of lemon juice, and fresh cilantro.

substitutions.note: Cook dried chickpeas for 45-60 minutes before using
Slightly chunkier texture but equally delicious
Adds richness but no longer vegan

title: Lamb Rogan Josh
description: A slow-cooked Kashmiri lamb curry with a deep red color from dried chiles, enriched with yogurt and aromatic whole spices.
steps: Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pot and fry the sliced onions over medium heat for 12-15 minutes until deeply caramelized.
Remove half the onions and set aside, then add the lamb pieces to the pot and brown on all sides.
Add cardamom, cinnamon, and bay leaves, stirring for 1 minute until fragrant.
Mix in kashmiri chili powder, ground fennel, and ground ginger, coating the lamb evenly.
Whisk the yogurt until smooth, then add it one tablespoon at a time, stirring constantly to prevent curdling.
Add 1 cup of water, the reserved onions, and saffron, then cover and simmer on low heat for 1.5 hours until the lamb is fork-tender.
Uncover, increase heat, and reduce the sauce until it clings to the meat, then serve with steamed basmati rice.

substitutions.note: Similar collagen content for a rich, tender stew
Loses some richness but makes it dairy-free when combined with coconut yogurt
Won't replicate the flavor but provides similar golden color

title: Kung Pao Chicken
description: A fiery Sichuan stir-fry of tender chicken, roasted peanuts, and dried chiles in a savory-sweet sauce with a tingle of Sichuan peppercorn.
steps: Toss the chicken cubes with 1 tbsp soy sauce, shaoxing wine, and cornstarch, and let marinate for 15 minutes.
Mix the sauce: combine remaining soy sauce, black vinegar, sugar, and 2 tbsp water in a small bowl.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat until smoking, then stir-fry the chicken for 3-4 minutes until just cooked through, and set aside.
In the same wok, add a splash more oil and fry the dried chiles and Sichuan peppercorns for 30 seconds until fragrant and darkened.
Add garlic and scallion whites, stir-fry for 30 seconds, then return the chicken to the wok.
Pour in the sauce, toss everything together, and cook for 1 minute until glossy and thickened.
Fold in the roasted peanuts and scallion greens, then serve immediately over steamed rice.

substitutions.note: Press for 30 minutes for best texture; makes it vegetarian
Similar dark color and sweet-tart profile

substitutions.replacement: black pepper with a tiny bit of lemon zest
substitutions.note: Won't replicate the numbing sensation but adds bite

title: Mapo Tofu
description: A bold Sichuan classic of silken tofu in a fiery, deeply savory sauce of fermented bean paste, ground pork, and Sichuan peppercorn.
steps: Gently simmer the tofu cubes in salted water for 3 minutes to warm through and firm up slightly, then drain carefully.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat and stir-fry the ground pork, breaking it up, until browned and crispy, about 4 minutes.
Push the pork to one side, add the doubanjiang to the oil, and fry for 1 minute until the oil turns red and fragrant.
Add garlic, ginger, and scallion whites, stirring for 30 seconds.
Pour in 3/4 cup water and soy sauce, bring to a simmer, then gently slide in the drained tofu cubes.
Simmer for 5 minutes, then stir in the cornstarch slurry and cook until the sauce thickens and coats the tofu.
Sprinkle with ground Sichuan peppercorn and scallion greens, and serve over steamed rice.

substitutions.note: Finely dice and pan-fry until crispy for a vegan version
1 tbsp each; slightly different flavor but good umami
Holds its shape better but less silky texture

title: Tonkotsu Ramen
description: A rich, milky pork bone broth ramen topped with chashu pork, soft-boiled egg, nori, and scallions — the ultimate comfort bowl.
steps: Blanch the pork bones in boiling water for 10 minutes, then drain and rinse thoroughly to remove impurities.

Return bones to a clean pot with garlic, ginger, and scallion whites, cover with fresh water, and bring to a rolling boil. Maintain a vigorous boil for 3-4 hours, adding water as needed, until the broth is opaque and milky.
Meanwhile, roll and tie the pork belly, sear in a hot pan, then braise in a mix of soy sauce, mirin, and water at 160°C/320°F for 2 hours until meltingly tender.
Soft-boil the eggs for 6.5 minutes, cool in ice water, peel, and marinate in the chashu braising liquid for at least 1 hour.
Strain the broth, discard the solids, and season with soy sauce and salt to taste.
Cook the ramen noodles according to package instructions, drain, and divide among bowls.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles, then top with sliced chashu pork, halved marinated eggs, nori, sliced scallions, and a drizzle of sesame oil.

substitutions.note: Makes a lighter, chicken paitan-style broth; boil for 2 hours
Low-carb alternative; rinse well before using
Braise for 45 minutes instead; slice thinly for topping

title: Vegetable Tempura
description: Light, shatteringly crispy Japanese tempura with an assortment of seasonal vegetables, served with a dashi-based dipping sauce.
steps: Prepare the dipping sauce (tentsuyu) by combining dashi, soy sauce, and mirin in a small saucepan, heating until just simmering, then set aside.
Heat vegetable oil to 170°C/340°F in a deep pot or fryer.
Whisk together the egg and ice-cold sparkling water, then add the flour all at once and stir briefly with chopsticks — the batter should be lumpy.
Pat all vegetables completely dry, dust lightly with extra flour, then dip into the batter, letting excess drip off.
Fry in small batches for 2-3 minutes until the batter is pale golden and crispy, flipping once.
Drain on a wire rack set over a baking sheet, and serve immediately with the warm tentsuyu dipping sauce and grated daikon if desired.

substitutions.note: Creates an extra-crispy, gluten-free batter
Chickpea liquid works as an egg replacement for vegan tempura
Simmer a piece of kombu in water for 10 minutes for vegetarian dashi

title: Pad Thai
description: Thailand's beloved stir-fried rice noodle dish with shrimp, scrambled egg, bean sprouts, and crushed peanuts in a tangy tamarind sauce.
steps: Soak the rice noodles in room-temperature water for 30 minutes until pliable, then drain.
Mix the pad thai sauce: combine tamarind paste, fish sauce, and palm sugar in a bowl, stirring until the sugar dissolves.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat, sear the shrimp for 1 minute per side, then remove and set aside.
Add a bit more oil, fry the tofu until golden on all sides, then push to one side. Crack in the eggs and scramble.
Add the drained noodles and the pad thai sauce, tossing with tongs for 2-3 minutes until the noodles are tender and coated.
Return the shrimp, add the scallions and half the bean sprouts, and toss for 1 more minute.
Serve topped with crushed peanuts, remaining bean sprouts, and lime wedges.

substitutions.note: Stir-fry for 3-4 minutes until cooked through
For a non-seafood alternative; adjust salt to taste
Similar caramel-like sweetness

title: Green Curry with Chicken
description: A vibrant and aromatic Thai green curry with tender chicken, Thai eggplant, and bamboo shoots swimming in rich coconut milk.
steps: Scoop the thick cream from the top of the coconut milk can into a wok over medium-high heat, and let it split and become oily.
Add the green curry paste and fry in the coconut cream for 2-3 minutes until very fragrant.
Add the sliced chicken and stir-fry for 3 minutes until the outside is sealed.
Pour in the remaining coconut milk, add kaffir lime leaves, eggplant, and bamboo shoots, then simmer for 12-15 minutes.
Season with fish sauce and palm sugar, adjusting the balance of salty and sweet to taste.
Stir in the Thai basil leaves just before serving, and serve over jasmine rice.

substitutions.note: Press and cube the tofu for a vegetarian version
Add in the last 5 minutes to avoid overcooking

substitutions.replacement: soy sauce with a pinch of seaweed powder
substitutions.note: For a vegan-friendly umami substitute

title: Classic Smash Burger
description: Thin, crispy-edged beef patties with melted American cheese, tangy pickles, and special sauce on a soft toasted bun.
steps: Mix mayonnaise, ketchup, and mustard together to make the special sauce and set aside.
Divide the ground beef into 8 equal balls (about 60g each) and season generously with salt and pepper.
Heat a cast-iron skillet or flat griddle over high heat until smoking hot.
Place a beef ball on the griddle and immediately smash it flat with a sturdy spatula, pressing hard for 10 seconds. Season the top with salt.
Cook without moving for 2-3 minutes until the edges are deeply browned and crispy, then lay a cheese slice on top and flip briefly to melt.
Toast the brioche buns cut-side down on the griddle for 30 seconds.
Assemble each burger with special sauce on both bun halves, two smashed patties with cheese, pickles, and sliced onion.

substitutions.note: Turkey is leaner; plant-based gives a vegetarian option
More flavor but doesn't melt as smoothly
For a low-carb or gluten-free option

title: Southern-Style Mac and Cheese
description: Creamy, baked macaroni and cheese with a blend of sharp cheddar, Gruyère, and a golden breadcrumb topping.
steps: Cook the macaroni in salted boiling water until just al dente, drain, and set aside.
Melt butter in a large saucepan over medium heat, whisk in flour, and cook the roux for 2 minutes.
Gradually pour in the milk while whisking constantly, and cook until the sauce thickens, about 5 minutes.
Remove from heat and stir in most of the cheddar and Gruyère (reserve some for topping), Dijon mustard, paprika, salt, and pepper.
Fold in the cooked macaroni, then pour into a greased baking dish.
Top with remaining cheese and panko breadcrumbs, and bake at 190°C/375°F for 20 minutes until golden and bubbling.

substitutions.note: Both melt well and have mild, nutty flavors
Use a sturdy shape like penne for best results

substitutions.replacement: oat milk with 1 tbsp nutritional yeast
substitutions.note: For a dairy-free béchamel; use vegan cheese too

title: Shakshuka
description: Eggs gently poached in a spiced, chunky tomato and bell pepper sauce with cumin, paprika, and crumbled feta.
steps: Heat olive oil in a large oven-safe skillet over medium heat, then sauté the onion and bell pepper for 6-7 minutes until softened.
Add garlic, cumin, paprika, and cayenne, stirring for 1 minute until fragrant.
Pour in the crushed tomatoes, season with salt and pepper, and simmer for 10 minutes until slightly thickened.
Make 6 wells in the sauce with a spoon and crack an egg into each well.
Cover the skillet and cook on low heat for 6-8 minutes until the egg whites are set but the yolks are still runny.
Scatter crumbled feta and fresh parsley over the top, and serve straight from the skillet with crusty bread for dipping.

substitutions.note: Creamier texture with similar tangy flavor
Nestle thick tofu slices into the sauce for a vegan version

substitutions.replacement: roasted red pepper and tomato mix
substitutions.note: Blend roasted peppers with tomatoes for a smokier base

title: Falafel Wrap
description: Crispy, herb-packed chickpea falafel tucked into warm pita with tahini sauce, pickled turnips, and fresh vegetables.
steps: Drain the soaked chickpeas thoroughly and pulse in a food processor with parsley, cilantro, onion, garlic, cumin, coriander, salt, and pepper until the mixture is coarse but holds together when pressed.
Stir in the baking powder, then refrigerate the mixture for 30 minutes to firm up.
Shape the mixture into walnut-sized balls, flattening slightly into discs.
Heat 5cm of oil to 175°C/350°F and fry the falafel in batches for 3-4 minutes until deeply golden and crispy, draining on paper towels.
Make the tahini sauce by whisking tahini with lemon juice, a pinch of salt, and water until it reaches a pourable consistency.
Warm the pita bread, fill with falafel, drizzle with tahini sauce, and add fresh tomato, cucumber, and pickled turnips.

substitutions.note: Egyptian-style falafel (ta'ameya); greener and lighter
For a low-carb, gluten-free wrap
Brush with oil and flip halfway; less crispy but lower fat

title: Coq au Vin
description: A classic French braise of chicken slowly simmered in red Burgundy wine with lardons, pearl onions, and mushrooms until fall-off-the-bone tender.
steps: Season the chicken pieces generously with salt and pepper. In a Dutch oven, render the lardons over medium heat until crispy, then remove and set aside.
Brown the chicken pieces in the bacon fat in batches, getting a deep golden crust on all sides, about 4 minutes per side. Remove and set aside.
Sauté the pearl onions and carrots in the same pot for 5 minutes, then add garlic and tomato paste, cooking for 1 more minute.
Deglaze with the entire bottle of red wine, scraping up all the fond, then add the chicken stock, thyme, and bay leaves.
Return the chicken and lardons to the pot, bring to a gentle simmer, then cover and cook in the oven at 160°C/325°F for 1.5 hours.
In a separate pan, sauté the mushrooms in butter until golden, then add to the pot in the last 15 minutes of cooking.
Remove the chicken, strain the sauce if desired, and reduce it on the stovetop until it coats the back of a spoon, then serve over the chicken.

substitutions.replacement: Pinot Noir or Côtes du Rhône
substitutions.note: Any dry, medium-bodied red wine works well
Italian cured pork belly; similar richness
Sweeter and easier to find; halve them lengthwise

title: Kimchi Jjigae
description: A deeply savory and spicy Korean stew made with well-fermented kimchi, pork belly, and silken tofu, perfect for cold weather.
steps: Heat sesame oil in a heavy pot over medium-high heat and stir-fry the pork belly slices until the fat starts to render, about 3 minutes.
Add the chopped kimchi and stir-fry together with the pork for 4-5 minutes until the kimchi is slightly caramelized.
Add gochugaru and garlic, stirring for 30 seconds.
Pour in the water or anchovy broth and kimchi brine, bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer and cook for 15 minutes.
Gently slide in large spoonfuls of soft tofu, keeping them in chunks, and simmer for another 5 minutes.
Taste and adjust with sugar or more kimchi brine, top with sliced scallions, and serve bubbling hot with steamed rice.

substitutions.note: A popular Korean variation called chamchi jjigae; add at the end
Milder and slightly fruity; use a bit more

substitutions.replacement: dashida (Korean beef stock powder) in water
substitutions.note: Convenient shortcut with good depth of flavor

title: Spanakopita
description: Flaky layers of golden phyllo pastry encasing a savory filling of spinach, feta, and fresh dill — a beloved Greek pie.
steps: Wilt the spinach in a large pan, then squeeze out as much moisture as possible using a clean tea towel.
Sauté the diced onion in olive oil until softened, then combine with the spinach, scallions, dill, crumbled feta, beaten eggs, nutmeg, salt, and pepper.
Brush a 9x13 inch baking dish with melted butter.
Layer 6 sheets of phyllo in the dish, brushing each sheet generously with melted butter, letting the edges overhang.
Spread the spinach filling evenly over the phyllo base.
Top with the remaining 6 phyllo sheets, again brushing each with butter, then tuck or roll the overhanging edges inward.
Score the top layers into squares or diamonds with a sharp knife, then bake at 180°C/350°F for 35-40 minutes until the phyllo is deeply golden and crispy.

substitutions.note: Richer and sturdier; no need to brush between layers
Milder and creamier; add extra salt
Squeeze very thoroughly; use 300g frozen

title: Beef Bourguignon
description: A French country-style beef stew braised low and slow in red wine with root vegetables, herbs, and pearl onions until meltingly tender.
steps: Pat the beef cubes dry, season with salt and pepper. Cook the bacon in a Dutch oven until crispy, remove, then sear the beef in batches in the bacon fat until browned on all sides.
Remove the beef, add carrots and pearl onions to the pot, and cook for 5 minutes until lightly colored.
Stir in garlic and tomato paste, cook for 1 minute, then sprinkle in the flour and stir to coat.
Deglaze with the red wine, scraping the bottom of the pot, then add the beef stock and bouquet garni.
Return the beef and bacon to the pot, bring to a simmer, cover, and transfer to the oven at 160°C/325°F for 2.5 hours.
In the last 30 minutes, sauté the mushrooms in butter until golden, then add them to the stew.
Remove the bouquet garni, adjust seasoning, and serve over mashed potatoes or egg noodles.

substitutions.note: Even more collagen for a richer, silkier sauce

substitutions.replacement: beef stock with 2 tbsp red wine vinegar
substitutions.note: For a non-alcoholic version; add a splash of grape juice for depth
Gluten-free thickener; add at the end mixed with cold water
